Persistence metric – stickiness

Getting started

“Stickiness”, a longitudinal persistence metric introduced in 2012, tracks all students who contact an instructional program to determine what percentage “stick” to that program and graduate in it.1

In this article, we show you how to use midfieldr to compute and compare the stickiness of several programs. Our workflow is:

  • select the programs
  • tally the students ever enrolled
  • tally the students graduating
  • compute stickiness
  • graph stickiness

In our example, the findings are disaggregated by program, sex, and race/ethnicity because our research questions focus on intersectionality. In your own work, you can decide to disaggregate (or not) on the variables of your choice.

library(midfieldr)       # midfieldr functions and CIP data
library(midfieldstudent) # student demographics and degree data
library(midfieldterm)    # term data

Select programs

For this example, we compare the stickiness of four engineering programs: Civil, Electrical, Industrial, and Mechanical. Their CIP codes were found by keyword search as illustrated in Selecting instructional programs.

Use cip_filter() to obtain the relevant program codes followed by add_column() to label the group of programs. These labels are handy later when we group and summarize the data.

library(dplyr)
library(tibble)
cve <- cip_filter("^1408") %>% add_column(PGRM = "CVE")
ele <- cip_filter("^1410") %>% add_column(PGRM = "ELE")
ise <- cip_filter("^1435") %>% add_column(PGRM = "ISE")
mce <- cip_filter("^1419") %>% add_column(PGRM = "MCE")

Bind the program data sets into one data frame and discard all but two variables.

# bind the four programs
programs <- bind_rows(cve, ele, ise, mce) %>% 
    select(CIP6, PGRM)

glimpse(programs)
#> Observations: 12
#> Variables: 2
#> $ CIP6 <chr> "140801", "140802", "140803", "140804", "140805", "140899...
#> $ PGRM <chr> "CVE", "CVE", "CVE", "CVE", "CVE", "CVE", "ELE", "ELE", "...
  • The CIP6 variable contains the patterns looked for using str_detect() to obtain the students we seek.
  • The PGRM variable is handy later when we group and summarize the data.

Tally students ever enrolled

We use the term dataset to find students ever enrolled in our programs.

# variables in term
names(term)
#>  [1] "MID"              "TYEAR"            "ENRSTAT"         
#>  [4] "TDESC"            "INSTCODE"         "TERMGPA"         
#>  [7] "CUMGPA"           "COOP"             "ONOFFCAMPUS"     
#> [10] "TTERM"            "INSTITUTION"      "TCIP"            
#> [13] "STULEVEL"         "ACADEMICSTANDING" "TCODE"           
#> [16] "TCIP2"            "TDESC2"           "TCODE2"          
#> [19] "TCIP3"            "TDESC3"           "TCODE3"          
#> [22] "BEGINYEAR"

Only a few of the 22 variables in term are needed to tally students ever enrolled. We delete as many variables as possible to improve execution time, selecting only those variables that contribute to the tally (e.g., MID or TCIP) or that might be useful as grouping variables (e.g., INSTITUTION).

# select the useful variables 
ever <- term %>% 
    select(MID, BEGINYEAR, TYEAR, TTERM, INSTITUTION, TCIP, TCIP2, TCIP3)

Gather all 6-digit codes (TCIP, TCIP2, TCIP3) in one column. Each observation in the resulting tidy data frame is a unique program per student. Thus the MID for students who change majors will appear in more than one row, once each per unique program.

# gather all CIPs in one column
library(tidyr)
ever <- ever %>% 
    gather(TCIPN, CIP6, TCIP:TCIP3) %>% 
    unique()

glimpse(ever)
#> Observations: 3,410,871
#> Variables: 7
#> $ MID         <dbl> 820100107, 820100135, 820100135, 820100156, 820100...
#> $ BEGINYEAR   <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA...
#> $ TYEAR       <dbl> 2005, 1998, 1999, 1993, 1993, 1993, 1992, 1994, 19...
#> $ TTERM       <chr> "FA", "FA", "SP", "SM", "FA", "SP", "FA", "SP", "S...
#> $ INSTITUTION <chr> "Institution 1", "Institution 1", "Institution 1",...
#> $ TCIPN       <chr> "TCIP", "TCIP", "TCIP", "TCIP", "TCIP", "TCIP", "T...
#> $ CIP6        <chr> "999999", "440701", "440701", "030601", "030601", ...

Filter ever for the rows with the desired programs.

# collapse the CIP6 vector to a search string
library(stringr)
series <- str_c(programs$CIP6, collapse = "|")

# keep only those programs in the search string
ever <- ever %>% 
    filter(str_detect(CIP6, series)) %>% 
    unique()

Join the program labels we created earlier in programs to the ever data frame.

# join the program labels
ever <- left_join(ever, programs, by = "CIP6") %>% 
    arrange(CIP6)
glimpse(ever)
#> Observations: 58,524
#> Variables: 8
#> $ MID         <dbl> 820102025, 820102025, 820102025, 820102025, 820102...
#> $ BEGINYEAR   <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA...
#> $ TYEAR       <dbl> 2004, 2003, 2004, 2004, 2005, 1990, 1991, 1991, 19...
#> $ TTERM       <chr> "SP", "FA", "FA", "SM", "SP", "FA", "SP", "FA", "S...
#> $ INSTITUTION <chr> "Institution 1", "Institution 1", "Institution 1",...
#> $ TCIPN       <chr> "TCIP", "TCIP", "TCIP", "TCIP", "TCIP", "TCIP", "T...
#> $ CIP6        <chr> "140801", "140801", "140801", "140801", "140801", ...
#> $ PGRM        <chr> "CVE", "CVE", "CVE", "CVE", "CVE", "CVE", "CVE", "...

Join the sex and ethnicity/race demographics from the student dataset to the ever data frame. (?join_demographics for more information.)

# add variables ETHNIC and SEX
ever <- join_demographics(ever)
glimpse(ever)
#> Observations: 58,524
#> Variables: 10
#> $ MID         <dbl> 820102025, 820102025, 820102025, 820102025, 820102...
#> $ BEGINYEAR   <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA...
#> $ TYEAR       <dbl> 2004, 2003, 2004, 2004, 2005, 1990, 1991, 1991, 19...
#> $ TTERM       <chr> "SP", "FA", "FA", "SM", "SP", "FA", "SP", "FA", "S...
#> $ INSTITUTION <chr> "Institution 1", "Institution 1", "Institution 1",...
#> $ TCIPN       <chr> "TCIP", "TCIP", "TCIP", "TCIP", "TCIP", "TCIP", "T...
#> $ CIP6        <chr> "140801", "140801", "140801", "140801", "140801", ...
#> $ PGRM        <chr> "CVE", "CVE", "CVE", "CVE", "CVE", "CVE", "CVE", "...
#> $ ETHNIC      <chr> "No Response", "No Response", "No Response", "No R...
#> $ SEX         <chr> "M", "M", "M", "M", "M", "M", "M", "M", "M", "M", ...

Finally, tally the ever-enrolled numbers by program, sex, and race/ethnicity.

Tally students graduating

Compute stickiness

Graph stickiness

  1. MW Ohland, MK Orr, RA Layton, SM Lord and RA Long, Introducing “stickiness” as a versatile metric of engineering persistence, 2012 Frontiers in Education Conference Proceedings, Seattle, WA, 2012, pp. 1-5. DOI 10.1109/FIE.2012.6462214. Stickiness is defined as the ratio of the number of students graduating in a program to the number of students ever enrolled in the program.↩
